The act of Congress lately passed authorizing the raising of an Engineer regiment permits the enlistment of all men who are or have been doing duty as Engineers, Pontoniers, or Pioneers. The original act sent to Washington was drafted by me and limited the men to be enlisted to present and former members of the Pioneeer Brigade. The act as passed was re-written in Washington and was not seen by me until after it had passed both houses and became a law. It would be manifestly unjust to insist upon the use of the full authority conferred by the law and therefore I have instructed all recruiting officers to decline enlisting any men from the Michigan Engineers, the 58th Indiana, or the Engineer Brigade who are not ex-Pioneers. As it would be legal, however, to do so I have authorized them to enlist other than ex-Pioneers on the written consent of regimental commanders. Wm E. Head Quarters Near Beans Station December 16th 1863 General Orders ) No 11 ) The following extracts of a letter captured in the skirmish of the 14th inst. and written by one of the enemy are published for the information of the Soldiers of the army. Perhaps you would lend me your attention for a few moments and let me recount the adventures & moves & draws of this Left-wing army of the Ohio we the 117 Regt. Indiana Vols Infy six month men have lead a checkered life for the past two & one half months. Weve seen that Elephant in a shape that few Indiana soldiers have seen him. We had seen fighting some of us. Our Col was in all the Vicksburg fights as Maj of the 8th but fighting of the soldiering by a long shot as you are well aware. In the last ten weeks we have marched nearly 500 miles and for the past two months have never drawn full rations. When we got to Morristown we were put on quarter rations. We went to Greensville 65 miles N.E. of Cumberland Gap and drew no rations for three days. Then drew meal and rations of fresh beef without salt. Corn had been issued to us as rations and we have had for days at a time absolutely nothing but parched corn and beef. Forty rounds of parched corn in your Haversacks was an order from Sergt Berry to his squad about a month ago. And it has passed into the Regt as a general order for every march. We retreated from Greenville on a run to Bulls Gap which we commenced fortifying and the paper stated our position as impregnable
[Page 2 of 3]
Before the Telegraph had given publicity to the news our impregnable position was evacuated and we are Skedaddling for Cumberland Gap. We had nothing to eat there for several days except a little and once or twice some parched corn. Our Brigade goes among the troops by the name of the Parched Corn Brigade Wilcoxs running Tigers. & the Lank Expectant Hoosey. We have been four times in hearing of several sharp little fights one in sight. But never yet in a skirmish. We marched & countermarched advanced and retreated and have killed a good many men by foolish running and unnecessary starvation. We went beyond Cumberland Gap into Ky. & there we went two days with nothing to eat save parched corn & meat which we foraged for. We drew some flour there that just lammed it to any thing you ever saw. If you would take the screenings from a flowering mill & to one bushel add a peck of oats & another peck of dirt & grind it all & you have a bushel & a half of the kind of flour that was issued to us on Yellow Creek Ky. I have a specimen of the bread & will save it until we the 117th Reg Ind Vol Infy. dd six months (thats or title, the swearing is not mine) are mustered out exhibited it in Indiana & then send it to Barnum for his celebrated museum. Strady hast. Quick ! Marching orders! We left Clich river on the 10th and advanced to the top of this mountain six miles from old camps. We are incamped right square in the gap where the wind whistles & [blows?] & cuts our cloths of our backs. It is awful cold here. Where at the base of the mountain it is as warm as summer. Rebs left here the day before we got here. They had several thousand at Beans Station
[Page 3 of 3]
The publication of the forgoing letter has been suggested by the knowledge of your own hardships & perils & that you might compare them with those of the enemy. And [see?] that they too have their privations which according to the writer of this letter far exceeds our own. If those who come upon our soil to invade us with the avowed purpose of subjugation can carry out their work under such trials, & with such gayety & cheerfulness as this letter exhibits far much more of that endurance, patience, & hope should you have, who are resisting tyranny and are fighting for you honor your homes & your liberty. Let it not be said that the heart of the invader is stronger & stouter than the determination of you, who fight for your all. Your wants are known to your Gen and every effort has been made to relieve them. Supplies of clothing & shoes have been ordered and are daily expected until they arrive you are called upon to support the signs of a severe and trying campaign, with the same manly fortitude & patience that has always been so honorable to you By Command of Lt. Gen Longstreet, Wm Small AAGen. Brig Gen L. C. Vaughn Comd. Brigd.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Note the soldier denoted as "Physically and Mentally deranged." Research shows younger Civil War soldiers who saw more comrades die or who were POWs had increased physical and mental ailments later in life.

Signed J. E. Johnson Gen

Provost Marshall Office Kingston Ga Nov 1863 Sir You will with your guard of one non commissioned officer and six men take charge of the Passenger Train on the Rome Rail Road and procede (sp) until further orders from Kingston to Rome Ga and return observing the following instructions. Examine the Pass-ports Orders, Furloughs, &c. of all persons, Citizens or Soldiers, male or female traveling on the Road, permit no citizens on the trains unless provided with Pass-ports arrest all officers or soldiers absent from their commands without proper authority, those arrested on upward bound trains you will turn over to Provost Marshall, at Rome, those arrested on down trains you will report to this office. Record the name, Rank, Regt, Co, and nature of Papers, of all officers or Soldiers traveling on the Road, also at what Station they take passage, and to what station they go, using the following form Rome R. R. ___ Date ________ 1863 Rank | Name | Report | Co. | From | To | on what papers | Remarks | ____________________________________________________________ Signed Officers Signature Day or night Train Deliver to the Officer of the Guard at Rome the list thus made, and receive from him his record of the Passengers on the train on which you may return, which record you will deposit in this office on arrival.
[Page 2 of 2]
No officer or Soldier belonging to the Army of Tenn, is permitted to leave the lines of the army unless their papers are approved at Hd. Qrs. army Tenn. All officers or soldiers found on the train without such authority will be arrested. Sick men, when placed on trains to go to Hospitals, must have the certificate of the Post Surgeon, of the Post at which they may take passage. No soldier is permitted to take with him his arms or accoutrements, when leaving the Army. All arms will be taken from such men turned over to the Ordinance officer. You will suppress disorder, interdict the use or introduction of intoxicating liquors on the cars, or its sale at any of the stations on the Road. Arrest all the intoxicated or disorderly persons. In loading trains at Atlanta, you will see that all persons belonging to the army are seated before allowing citizens on the trains. When there is sufficient room, citizens may be admitted in the cars, but Soldiers always take precedence. All citizens leaving Atlanta must have Pass-ports from this office, and no citizen will be permitted to go beyond Dalton Ga, unless provided with Pass-ports from Hd. Qrs. Army of Tenn. You will see that no persons are permitted to stand or sit on the platform of the cars. You will report at this office immediately on arrival and within one hour prior to departure of trains. For officer of Guard, Rome R. R. By order of J. P. Baltzell /Capt. & P. M.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter ordering an officer to go with a guard of one non-commissioned officer and six men in order to take charge of a passenger train on the Rome Railroad; the letter includes additional instructions. An example of the form to be kept is hand-drawn at the bottom of first page. The letter is signed by Captain and Provost Marshal J. P. Baltzelle.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Confederate States of America -- War Dept.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Records were to be kept of railroad passengers, and were to include the following information: name and rank; regiment and company; traveling from; traveling to; on what papers/authority; remarks. Though Army Regulations Volumes conveyed the format of basic military forms, this document illustrates another method used to pass along the proper form to maintain.
